categories.title: ElizaOS Development Updates and Technical Discussions - January 16, 2026

content.text: Token Price Manipulation and Investment Concerns: Community members discussed significant price manipulation of the ElizaOS token by whales controlling large portions of the supply. Users noted continuous downward pressure resembling team selling to cover expenses, with the token dropping back under 3 cents despite brief recovery attempts. Multiple users emphasized that investors should have sold during pumps, as the price action is unnatural and the token carries high risk. Some members reported being down 60 percent after entering post-pump. The consensus was that while the project itself is interesting, the token performance has been poor, with advice to only invest what one can afford to lose.

Security Alert - Fake Hash LLM Repository: Community members identified a suspicious GitHub repository under the username ctrlshifthash claiming to be Hash LLM with faked commits appearing to be from core team members. The account was following Shaw and linked to official repositories, causing initial confusion. Core developers clarified that any commits can be faked in Git by using anyone's email addresses, and that these were commits moved from other projects. The team confirmed that if something is not in official announcements, it is not legitimate. Users were reminded to verify authenticity through official channels only.

Sentien Space Development Progress: Developer miami0x shared updates on Sentien Space, showcasing an agentic onboarding process where users can set up accounts through voice or text prompts with the AI agent Nikita instead of filling traditional forms. The system allows users to literally prompt their profile creation, which the developer noted has never been built before. The team plans to open source Sentien Space and believes the technology will attract more engineers to build the future of social platforms. The project is preparing to launch on Binance Square.

Advanced Solana Trading Infrastructure Discussion: An experienced blockchain developer shared their sophisticated Solana trading infrastructure built using GRPC real-time streaming rather than traditional APIs. The system handles approximately 600 transactions per second with transfers averaging under 150 milliseconds using stacked nodes. The infrastructure includes real-time feeds from 5,000 Twitter accounts, token tracking, PNL and FDV monitoring directly from program IDs, and detection of bundles, KOL activity, developer sells, rugs, and holder transactions. The developer uses Yellowstone Dragon's Mouth GRPC streaming and Jito's ShredStream for ultra-fast data transmission, providing approximately 32 milliseconds improvement over standard methods. The system is built primarily in Rust and automatically creates trackers for tokens with smart exits at different levels including trailing stops and volume-based exits. The developer is exploring integrating ElizaOS to automate an autonomous launcher agent based on hot trends, narratives, and breaking news from Twitter feeds.

Token Creation and Twitter Feed Integration Demos: A developer demonstrated live token creation functionality and Twitter feed integration working in real-time. The demonstrations showed automated token launching capabilities and social media monitoring features being successfully implemented.

ChatVRM and ElizaOS Integration: Developer Supreem showcased a heavily modified ChatVRM integrated with ElizaOS using Together.ai for unmoderated models, Tavily web search plugin, and ElevenLabs for text-to-speech. The implementation includes a 3D character interface with the VRM model found in a brandkit GitHub repository. The demonstration received positive feedback from the community.

Spartan Trading Bot Technical Clarifications: Discussion around Spartan revealed it uses APIs rather than real-time on-chain data, leading to questions about profitability. Core developer Odilitime offered to answer Spartan-related questions and acknowledged that plugin-Solana could benefit from a GRPC option. The conversation highlighted differences between API-based approaches and direct blockchain streaming methods.

Core Development Priorities and Code Refactoring: Shaw confirmed completing action parameters work and clarified that messageService is being used rather than alternative approaches. The team prioritized finishing cloud and app creation before launch, with freelancers reviewing examples and Rust and Python implementations. Stan submitted a significant refactoring pull request for plugin-sql, extracting domain stores from BaseDrizzleAdapter to improve maintainability and testability without changing the public API. After resolving merge conflicts and ensuring tests passed, the team decided to potentially save some changes for version 2.x pending Shaw's final decision.

OpenWork AI Launch: The team shared the launch of OpenWork AI, an open-source MIT-licensed computer-use agent that is fast, cheap, and secure. The project resulted from a two-day hackathon bringing together favorite open source AI modules.

The ElizaOS project made significant progress on January 16, 2026, focusing on internal code improvements and user experience enhancements. The team refactored the BaseDrizzleAdapter in the plugin-sql package to extract domain stores, improving code maintainability and separation of concerns while keeping the public API unchanged. Two user-facing issues were successfully resolved: the removal of '+' symbols from personality traits and topics of interest fields for a cleaner interface, and a fix for the login/signup redirection problem that was incorrectly sending users to the dashboard instead of their previous agent chat session.

Three new issues were opened for consideration. The first proposes adding the ability to deploy smart contracts on-chain. The second suggests integrating Opus 4.5 into applications. The third is a critical bug report concerning a migration eligibility mismatch and snapshot bug related to a Tangem hardware wallet and $ai16z holdings, which requires investigation.
